Lesson 10: Visualising and Analysing Time-oriented Data

10.1 Learning Outcome

By the end of this hands-on exercise , will be able create the followings data visualisation by using R packages:

  • plotting a calender heatmap by using ggplot2 functions,

  • plotting a cycle plot by using ggplot2 function,

  • plotting a slopegraph

  • plotting a horizon chart

10.2 Getting Started

10.3 Loading packages

Installing and launch the following R packages: scales, viridis, lubridate, ggthemes, gridExtra, readxl, knitr, data.table and tidyverse.

pacman::p_load(scales, viridis, lubridate, ggthemes,
               gridExtra, readxl, knitr, data.table,
               CGPfunctions, ggHoriPlot, tidyverse)

10.4 Plotting Calendar Heatmap

In this section, will learn how to plot a calender heatmap programmatically by using ggplot2 package.

  • plot a calender heatmap by using ggplot2 functions and extension,

  • to write function using R programming,

  • to derive specific date and time related field by using base R and lubridate packages

  • to perform data preparation task by using tidyr and dplyr packages.

10.4.1 The Data

For the purpose of this hands-on exercise, eventlog.csv file will be used. This data file consists of 199,999 rows of time-series cyber attack records by country.

10.4.2 Importing the data

First, you will use the code chunk below to import eventlog.csv file into R environment and called the data frame as attacks.

attacks <- read_csv("data/eventlog.csv")

10.4.3 Examining the data structure

It is always a good practice to examine the imported data frame before further analysis is performed.

For example, kable() can be used to review the structure of the imported data frame.

kable(head(attacks))
timestamp source_country tz
2015-03-12 15:59:16 CN Asia/Shanghai
2015-03-12 16:00:48 FR Europe/Paris
2015-03-12 16:02:26 CN Asia/Shanghai
2015-03-12 16:02:38 US America/Chicago
2015-03-12 16:03:22 CN Asia/Shanghai
2015-03-12 16:03:45 CN Asia/Shanghai

Referring to above list, There are three columns, namely timestamp, source_country and tz.

  • timestamp field stores date-time values in POSIXct format.

  • source_country field stores the source of the attack. It is in ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code.

  • tz field stores time zone of the source IP address.

10.4.4 Data Preparation

Step 1: Deriving weekday and hour of day fields

Before we can plot the calender heatmap, two new fields namely wkday and hour need to be derived.

In this step, we will write a function to perform the task.

make_hr_wkday <- function(ts, sc, tz) {
  real_times <- ymd_hms(ts, 
                        tz = tz[1], 
                        quiet = TRUE)
  dt <- data.table(source_country = sc,
                   wkday = weekdays(real_times),
                   hour = hour(real_times))
  return(dt)
  }
Note

  • ymd_hms() and hour() are from lubridate package, and

  • weekdays() is a base R function.

Step 2: Deriving the attacks tibble data frame

wkday_levels <- c('Saturday', 'Friday', 
                  'Thursday', 'Wednesday', 
                  'Tuesday', 'Monday', 
                  'Sunday')

attacks <- attacks %>%
  group_by(tz) %>%
  do(make_hr_wkday(.$timestamp, 
                   .$source_country, 
                   .$tz)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(wkday = factor(
    wkday, levels = wkday_levels),
    hour  = factor(
      hour, levels = 0:23))
Note

Beside extracting the necessary data into attacks data frame, mutate() of dplyr package is used to convert wkday and hour fields into factor so they’ll be ordered when plotting

Explain the above code chunk:

  • group_by(tz): Split the data by each time-zone (tz) value.

  • do(make_hr_wkday(...)): For each group, call your helper function make_hr_wkday(), which returns a small table with three columns:

  1. source_country (passed through)

  2. wkday (the weekday name of each timestamp)

  3. hour (the hour of day, 0–23)

  • ungroup(): Recombine all those group outputs back into one big tibble.

  • mutate(...): Convert both wkday and hour into ordered factors with the levels you specified. That way, when you plot or tabulate, the categories will appear in chronological order (Sat → Fri → … → Sun and 0 → 1 → … → 23).

Table below shows the tidy tibble table after processing.

kable(head(attacks))
tz source_country wkday hour
Africa/Cairo BG Saturday 20
Africa/Cairo TW Sunday 6
Africa/Cairo TW Sunday 8
Africa/Cairo CN Sunday 11
Africa/Cairo US Sunday 15
Africa/Cairo CA Monday 11

10.4.5 Building the Calendar Heatmaps

grouped <- attacks %>% 
  count(wkday, hour) %>% 
  ungroup() %>%
  na.omit()

ggplot(grouped, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
coord_equal() +
scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
labs(x = NULL, 
     y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks by weekday and time of day") +
theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
      plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
      legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
      legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )
Things to learn from the code above:

  • a tibble data table called grouped is derived by aggregating the attack by wkday and hour fields.

  • a new field called n is derived by using group_by() and count() functions.

  • na.omit() is used to exclude missing value.

  • geom_tile() is used to plot tiles (grids) at each x and y position. color and size arguments are used to specify the border color and line size of the tiles.

  • theme_tufte() of ggthemes package is used to remove unnecessary chart junk. To learn which visual components of default ggplot2 have been excluded, you are encouraged to comment out this line to examine the default plot.

  • coord_equal() is used to ensure the plot will have an aspect ratio of 1:1.

  • scale_fill_gradient() function is used to creates a two colour gradient (low-high).

explain the above code

# 1. Summarise attacks by weekday & hour
grouped <- attacks %>%
  count(wkday, hour) %>%   # 2. Count rows for each (wkday, hour) → creates column `n`
  ungroup() %>%            # 3. Drop any grouping metadata
  na.omit()                # 4. Remove rows with NA in wkday, hour, or n

# 5. Build the calendar‐style heatmap
ggplot(grouped,
       aes(x = hour,
           y = wkday,
           fill = n)) +       # 6. Map `hour` → x, `wkday` → y, `n` → fill color
  geom_tile(color = "white",
            size  = 0.1) +    # 7. Draw each cell as a tile with a thin white border
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") +  # 8. Apply a clean Tufte theme with Helvetica font
  coord_equal() +                       # 9. Ensure x and y scales use equal units (square tiles)
  scale_fill_gradient(
    name = "# of attacks",     # 10. Legend title
    low  = "sky blue",         # 11. Color for low values
    high = "dark blue"         # 12. Color for high values
  ) +
  labs(
    x     = NULL,              # 13. Remove x‐axis label
    y     = NULL,              # 14. Remove y‐axis label
    title = "Attacks by weekday and time of day"  # 15. Plot title
  ) +
  theme(
    axis.ticks   = element_blank(),             # 16. Hide axis tick marks
    plot.title   = element_text(hjust = 0.5),   # 17. Center the title
    legend.title = element_text(size = 8),      # 18. Legend title font size
    legend.text  = element_text(size = 6)       # 19. Legend item font size
  )

Then we can simply group the count by hour and wkday and plot it, since we know that we have values for every combination there’s no need to further preprocess the data.

10.4.6 Building Multiple Calendar Heatmaps [Unassisted Trial]

Building multiple heatmaps for the top four countries with the highest number of attacks.

# indentify the top 4 source countries by total attack count
top4 <- attacks %>%
  count(source_country) %>%   #count for total attacks per country
  arrange(desc(n)) %>%        #sort by descending order
  slice_head(n = 4) %>%       #take the first 4 (top 4) 
  pull(source_country)        #extract the country names

# build weekday/hour counts for those top 4 countries
grouped_top4 <- attacks %>%
  filter(source_country %in% top4) %>%   #only keep top 4 countries
  count(source_country, wkday, hour) %>% #count attack per (source_contry,wkday,hour)
  ungroup() %>%
  na.omit()  #drop any rows with NA


ggplot(grouped_top4, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
facet_wrap(~ source_country, ncol = 2) +    # 2 column of small heatmaps
theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
coord_equal() +
scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
labs(x = NULL, 
     y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks by weekday and time of day") +
theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
      axis.text.x = element_text(size = 5),
      plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
      legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
      legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )

10.4.7 Plotting Multiple Calendar Heatmaps

Step 1: Deriving attack by country object

In order to identify the top 4 countries with the highest number of attacks, required to do the followings:

  • count the number of attacks by country,

  • calculate the percent of attackes by country, and

  • save the results in a tibble data frame.

attacks_by_country <- count(
  attacks, source_country) %>%
  mutate(percent = percent(n/sum(n))) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))

Step 2: Preparing the tidy data frame

In this step, required to extract the attack records of the top 4 countries from attacks data frame and save the data in a new tibble data frame (i.e. top4_attacks).

top4 <- attacks_by_country$source_country[1:4]
top4_attacks <- attacks %>%
  filter(source_country %in% top4) %>%
  count(source_country, wkday, hour) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(source_country = factor(
    source_country, levels = top4)) %>%
  na.omit()
Self-note

mutate(source_country = factor(source_country, levels = top4))

the purpose is to convert the source_country column into a categorical factor whose categories are ordered exactly as in the top4 vector.

Reason：By default, R will sort or display character group by alphabetically or first appearance, so now convert to a factor with own levels, so that when facet or order data, the four countries appear in the Top 4 sequence.

10.4.8 Plotting Multiple Calendar Heatmaps

Step 3: Plotting the Multiple Calender Heatmap by using ggplot2 package.

ggplot(top4_attacks, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
  geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
  coord_equal() +
  scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
  facet_wrap(~source_country, ncol = 2) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks on top 4 countries by weekday and time of day") +
  theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 7),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )
